modules.name: sqlite
modules.desc:
Source Code: lib/sqlite.js

The node:sqlite module facilitates working with SQLite databases. To access it:

import sqlite from 'node:sqlite';

const sqlite = require('node:sqlite');

This module is only available under the node: scheme.

The following example shows the basic usage of the node:sqlite module to open an in-memory database, write data to the database, and then read the data back.

import { DatabaseSync } from 'node:sqlite';
const database = new DatabaseSync(':memory:');

// Execute SQL statements from strings.
database.exec(`
  CREATE TABLE data(
    key INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
    value TEXT
  ) STRICT
`);
// Create a prepared statement to insert data into the database.
const insert = database.prepare('INSERT INTO data (key, value) VALUES (?, ?)');
// Execute the prepared statement with bound values.
insert.run(1, 'hello');
insert.run(2, 'world');
// Create a prepared statement to read data from the database.
const query = database.prepare('SELECT * FROM data ORDER BY key');
// Execute the prepared statement and log the result set.
console.log(query.all());
// Prints: [ { key: 1, value: 'hello' }, { key: 2, value: 'world' } ]

'use strict';
const { DatabaseSync } = require('node:sqlite');
const database = new DatabaseSync(':memory:');

// Execute SQL statements from strings.
database.exec(`
  CREATE TABLE data(
    key INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
    value TEXT
  ) STRICT
`);
// Create a prepared statement to insert data into the database.
const insert = database.prepare('INSERT INTO data (key, value) VALUES (?, ?)');
// Execute the prepared statement with bound values.
insert.run(1, 'hello');
insert.run(2, 'world');
// Create a prepared statement to read data from the database.
const query = database.prepare('SELECT * FROM data ORDER BY key');
// Execute the prepared statement and log the result set.
console.log(query.all());
// Prints: [ { key: 1, value: 'hello' }, { key: 2, value: 'world' } ]

classes.name: DatabaseSync

changes.description: The `path` argument now supports Buffer and URL objects.

classes.desc: This class represents a single connection to a SQLite database. All APIs exposed by this class execute synchronously.

methods.name: close
methods.desc: Closes the database connection. An exception is thrown if the database is not open. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3_close_v2().

methods.name: loadExtension

params.textRaw: `path` {string} The path to the shared library to load.
params.name: path
params.desc: The path to the shared library to load.

methods.desc: Loads a shared library into the database connection. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3_load_extension(). It is required to enable the allowExtension option when constructing the DatabaseSync instance.

methods.name: enableLoadExtension

params.textRaw: `allow` {boolean} Whether to allow loading extensions.
params.name: allow
params.desc: Whether to allow loading extensions.

methods.desc: Enables or disables the loadExtension SQL function, and the loadExtension() method. When allowExtension is false when constructing, you cannot enable loading extensions for security reasons.

methods.name: exec

params.textRaw: `sql` {string} A SQL string to execute.
params.name: sql
params.desc: A SQL string to execute.

methods.desc: This method allows one or more SQL statements to be executed without returning any results. This method is useful when executing SQL statements read from a file. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3_exec().

methods.name: function

params.textRaw: `name` {string} The name of the SQLite function to create.
params.name: name
params.desc: The name of the SQLite function to create.

params.textRaw: `options` {Object} Optional configuration settings for the function. The following properties are supported:
params.name: options
params.desc: Optional configuration settings for the function. The following properties are supported:

options.textRaw: `deterministic` {boolean} If `true`, the [`SQLITE_DETERMINISTIC`][] flag is set on the created function. **Default:** `false`.
options.name: deterministic
options.desc: If `true`, the [`SQLITE_DETERMINISTIC`][] flag is set on the created function.

options.textRaw: `directOnly` {boolean} If `true`, the [`SQLITE_DIRECTONLY`][] flag is set on the created function. **Default:** `false`.
options.name: directOnly
options.desc: If `true`, the [`SQLITE_DIRECTONLY`][] flag is set on the created function.

options.textRaw: `useBigIntArguments` {boolean} If `true`, integer arguments to `function` are converted to `BigInt`s. If `false`, integer arguments are passed as JavaScript numbers. **Default:** `false`.
options.name: useBigIntArguments
options.desc: If `true`, integer arguments to `function` are converted to `BigInt`s. If `false`, integer arguments are passed as JavaScript numbers.

options.textRaw: `varargs` {boolean} If `true`, `function` may be invoked with any number of arguments (between zero and [`SQLITE_MAX_FUNCTION_ARG`][]). If `false`, `function` must be invoked with exactly `function.length` arguments. **Default:** `false`.
options.name: varargs
options.desc: If `true`, `function` may be invoked with any number of arguments (between zero and [`SQLITE_MAX_FUNCTION_ARG`][]). If `false`, `function` must be invoked with exactly `function.length` arguments.

params.textRaw: `function` {Function} The JavaScript function to call when the SQLite function is invoked. The return value of this function should be a valid SQLite data type: see [Type conversion between JavaScript and SQLite][]. The result defaults to `NULL` if the return value is `undefined`.
params.name: function
params.desc: The JavaScript function to call when the SQLite function is invoked. The return value of this function should be a valid SQLite data type: see [Type conversion between JavaScript and SQLite][]. The result defaults to `NULL` if the return value is `undefined`.

methods.desc: This method is used to create SQLite user-defined functions. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3_create_function_v2().

methods.name: open
methods.desc: Opens the database specified in the path argument of the DatabaseSync constructor. This method should only be used when the database is not opened via the constructor. An exception is thrown if the database is already open.

methods.name: prepare

params.textRaw: `sql` {string} A SQL string to compile to a prepared statement.
params.name: sql
params.desc: A SQL string to compile to a prepared statement.

methods.desc: Compiles a SQL statement into a prepared statement. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3_prepare_v2().

methods.name: createSession

params.textRaw: `options` {Object} The configuration options for the session.
params.name: options
params.desc: The configuration options for the session.

options.textRaw: `table` {string} A specific table to track changes for. By default, changes to all tables are tracked.
options.name: table
options.desc: A specific table to track changes for. By default, changes to all tables are tracked.

options.textRaw: `db` {string} Name of the database to track. This is useful when multiple databases have been added using [`ATTACH DATABASE`][]. **Default**: `'main'`.
options.name: db
options.desc: Name of the database to track. This is useful when multiple databases have been added using [`ATTACH DATABASE`][]. **Default**: `'main'`.

methods.desc: Creates and attaches a session to the database. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3session_create() and sqlite3session_attach().

methods.name: applyChangeset

return.textRaw: Returns: {boolean} Whether the changeset was applied successfully without being aborted.
return.name: return
return.desc: Whether the changeset was applied successfully without being aborted.

params.textRaw: `changeset` {Uint8Array} A binary changeset or patchset.
params.name: changeset
params.desc: A binary changeset or patchset.

params.textRaw: `options` {Object} The configuration options for how the changes will be applied.
params.name: options
params.desc: The configuration options for how the changes will be applied.

options.textRaw: `filter` {Function} Skip changes that, when targeted table name is supplied to this function, return a truthy value. By default, all changes are attempted.
options.name: filter
options.desc: Skip changes that, when targeted table name is supplied to this function, return a truthy value. By default, all changes are attempted.

options.textRaw: `onConflict` {Function} A function that determines how to handle conflicts. The function receives one argument, which can be one of the following values:The function should return one of the following values:When an error is thrown in the conflict handler or when any other value is returned from the handler, applying the changeset is aborted and the database is rolled back.**Default**: A function that returns `SQLITE_CHANGESET_ABORT`.
options.name: onConflict
options.desc: A function that determines how to handle conflicts. The function receives one argument, which can be one of the following values:The function should return one of the following values:When an error is thrown in the conflict handler or when any other value is returned from the handler, applying the changeset is aborted and the database is rolled back.**Default**: A function that returns `SQLITE_CHANGESET_ABORT`.

options.textRaw: `SQLITE_CHANGESET_DATA`: A `DELETE` or `UPDATE` change does not contain the expected "before" values.
options.name: SQLITE_CHANGESET_DATA
options.desc: A `DELETE` or `UPDATE` change does not contain the expected "before" values.

options.textRaw: `SQLITE_CHANGESET_NOTFOUND`: A row matching the primary key of the `DELETE` or `UPDATE` change does not exist.
options.name: SQLITE_CHANGESET_NOTFOUND
options.desc: A row matching the primary key of the `DELETE` or `UPDATE` change does not exist.

options.textRaw: `SQLITE_CHANGESET_CONFLICT`: An `INSERT` change results in a duplicate primary key.
options.name: SQLITE_CHANGESET_CONFLICT
options.desc: An `INSERT` change results in a duplicate primary key.

options.textRaw: `SQLITE_CHANGESET_FOREIGN_KEY`: Applying a change would result in a foreign key violation.
options.name: SQLITE_CHANGESET_FOREIGN_KEY
options.desc: Applying a change would result in a foreign key violation.

options.textRaw: `SQLITE_CHANGESET_CONSTRAINT`: Applying a change results in a `UNIQUE`, `CHECK`, or `NOT NULL` constraint violation.
options.name: SQLITE_CHANGESET_CONSTRAINT
options.desc: Applying a change results in a `UNIQUE`, `CHECK`, or `NOT NULL` constraint violation.

methods.desc:
An exception is thrown if the database is not open. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3changeset_apply().

const sourceDb = new DatabaseSync(':memory:');
const targetDb = new DatabaseSync(':memory:');

sourceDb.exec('CREATE TABLE data(key INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, value TEXT)');
targetDb.exec('CREATE TABLE data(key INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, value TEXT)');

const session = sourceDb.createSession();

const insert = sourceDb.prepare('INSERT INTO data (key, value) VALUES (?, ?)');
insert.run(1, 'hello');
insert.run(2, 'world');

const changeset = session.changeset();
targetDb.applyChangeset(changeset);
// Now that the changeset has been applied, targetDb contains the same data as sourceDb.

methods.name: [Symbol.dispose]
methods.desc: Closes the database connection. If the database connection is already closed then this is a no-op.

properties.textRaw: `isOpen` {boolean} Whether the database is currently open or not.
properties.name: isOpen
properties.desc: Whether the database is currently open or not.

params.textRaw: `path` {string | Buffer | URL} The path of the database. A SQLite database can be stored in a file or completely [in memory][]. To use a file-backed database, the path should be a file path. To use an in-memory database, the path should be the special name `':memory:'`.
params.name: path
params.desc: The path of the database. A SQLite database can be stored in a file or completely [in memory][]. To use a file-backed database, the path should be a file path. To use an in-memory database, the path should be the special name `':memory:'`.

params.textRaw: `options` {Object} Configuration options for the database connection. The following options are supported:
params.name: options
params.desc: Configuration options for the database connection. The following options are supported:

options.textRaw: `open` {boolean} If `true`, the database is opened by the constructor. When this value is `false`, the database must be opened via the `open()` method. **Default:** `true`.
options.name: open
options.desc: If `true`, the database is opened by the constructor. When this value is `false`, the database must be opened via the `open()` method.

options.textRaw: `readOnly` {boolean} If `true`, the database is opened in read-only mode. If the database does not exist, opening it will fail. **Default:** `false`.
options.name: readOnly
options.desc: If `true`, the database is opened in read-only mode. If the database does not exist, opening it will fail.

options.textRaw: `enableForeignKeyConstraints` {boolean} If `true`, foreign key constraints are enabled. This is recommended but can be disabled for compatibility with legacy database schemas. The enforcement of foreign key constraints can be enabled and disabled after opening the database using [`PRAGMA foreign_keys`][]. **Default:** `true`.
options.name: enableForeignKeyConstraints
options.desc: If `true`, foreign key constraints are enabled. This is recommended but can be disabled for compatibility with legacy database schemas. The enforcement of foreign key constraints can be enabled and disabled after opening the database using [`PRAGMA foreign_keys`][].

options.textRaw: `enableDoubleQuotedStringLiterals` {boolean} If `true`, SQLite will accept [double-quoted string literals][]. This is not recommended but can be enabled for compatibility with legacy database schemas. **Default:** `false`.
options.name: enableDoubleQuotedStringLiterals
options.desc: If `true`, SQLite will accept [double-quoted string literals][]. This is not recommended but can be enabled for compatibility with legacy database schemas.

options.textRaw: `allowExtension` {boolean} If `true`, the `loadExtension` SQL function and the `loadExtension()` method are enabled. You can call `enableLoadExtension(false)` later to disable this feature. **Default:** `false`.
options.name: allowExtension
options.desc: If `true`, the `loadExtension` SQL function and the `loadExtension()` method are enabled. You can call `enableLoadExtension(false)` later to disable this feature.

methods.name: changeset

return.textRaw: Returns: {Uint8Array} Binary changeset that can be applied to other databases.
return.name: return
return.desc: Binary changeset that can be applied to other databases.

methods.desc: Retrieves a changeset containing all changes since the changeset was created. Can be called multiple times. An exception is thrown if the database or the session is not open. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3session_changeset().

methods.name: patchset

return.textRaw: Returns: {Uint8Array} Binary patchset that can be applied to other databases.
return.name: return
return.desc: Binary patchset that can be applied to other databases.

methods.desc: Similar to the method above, but generates a more compact patchset. See Changesets and Patchsets in the documentation of SQLite. An exception is thrown if the database or the session is not open. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3session_patchset().

modules.name: `session.close()`.
modules.desc: Closes the session. An exception is thrown if the database or the session is not open. This method is a wrapper around sqlite3session_delete().

classes.name: StatementSync
classes.desc:
This class represents a single prepared statement. This class cannot be instantiated via its constructor. Instead, instances are created via the database.prepare() method. All APIs exposed by this class execute synchronously.

A prepared statement is an efficient binary representation of the SQL used to create it. Prepared statements are parameterizable, and can be invoked multiple times with different bound values. Parameters also offer protection against SQL injection attacks. For these reasons, prepared statements are preferred over hand-crafted SQL strings when handling user input.

methods.name: all

changes.description: Add support for `DataView` and typed array objects for `anonymousParameters`.

return.textRaw: Returns: {Array} An array of objects. Each object corresponds to a row returned by executing the prepared statement. The keys and values of each object correspond to the column names and values of the row.
return.name: return
return.desc: An array of objects. Each object corresponds to a row returned by executing the prepared statement. The keys and values of each object correspond to the column names and values of the row.

params.textRaw: `namedParameters` {Object} An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.
params.name: namedParameters
params.desc: An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.

params.textRaw: `...anonymousParameters` {null|number|bigint|string|Buffer|TypedArray|DataView} Zero or more values to bind to anonymous parameters.
params.name: ...anonymousParameters
params.desc: Zero or more values to bind to anonymous parameters.

methods.desc: This method executes a prepared statement and returns all results as an array of objects. If the prepared statement does not return any results, this method returns an empty array. The prepared statement parameters are bound using the values in namedParameters and anonymousParameters.

methods.name: columns

return.textRaw: Returns: {Array} An array of objects. Each object corresponds to a column in the prepared statement, and contains the following properties:
return.name: return
return.desc: An array of objects. Each object corresponds to a column in the prepared statement, and contains the following properties:

options.textRaw: `column`: {string|null} The unaliased name of the column in the origin table, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_origin_name()`][].
options.name: column
options.desc: The unaliased name of the column in the origin table, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_origin_name()`][].

options.textRaw: `database`: {string|null} The unaliased name of the origin database, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_database_name()`][].
options.name: database
options.desc: The unaliased name of the origin database, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_database_name()`][].

options.textRaw: `name`: {string} The name assigned to the column in the result set of a `SELECT` statement. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_name()`][].
options.name: name
options.desc: The name assigned to the column in the result set of a `SELECT` statement. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_name()`][].

options.textRaw: `table`: {string|null} The unaliased name of the origin table, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_table_name()`][].
options.name: table
options.desc: The unaliased name of the origin table, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_table_name()`][].

options.textRaw: `type`: {string|null} The declared data type of the column, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_decltype()`][].
options.name: type
options.desc: The declared data type of the column, or `null` if the column is the result of an expression or subquery. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_column_decltype()`][].

methods.desc: This method is used to retrieve information about the columns returned by the prepared statement.

changes.description: Add support for `DataView` and typed array objects for `anonymousParameters`.

return.textRaw: Returns: {Object|undefined} An object corresponding to the first row returned by executing the prepared statement. The keys and values of the object correspond to the column names and values of the row. If no rows were returned from the database then this method returns `undefined`.
return.name: return
return.desc: An object corresponding to the first row returned by executing the prepared statement. The keys and values of the object correspond to the column names and values of the row. If no rows were returned from the database then this method returns `undefined`.

params.textRaw: `namedParameters` {Object} An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.
params.name: namedParameters
params.desc: An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.

params.name: ...anonymousParameters
params.desc: Zero or more values to bind to anonymous parameters.

methods.desc: This method executes a prepared statement and returns the first result as an object. If the prepared statement does not return any results, this method returns undefined. The prepared statement parameters are bound using the values in namedParameters and anonymousParameters.

methods.name: iterate

changes.description: Add support for `DataView` and typed array objects for `anonymousParameters`.

return.textRaw: Returns: {Iterator} An iterable iterator of objects. Each object corresponds to a row returned by executing the prepared statement. The keys and values of each object correspond to the column names and values of the row.
return.name: return
return.desc: An iterable iterator of objects. Each object corresponds to a row returned by executing the prepared statement. The keys and values of each object correspond to the column names and values of the row.

params.textRaw: `namedParameters` {Object} An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.
params.name: namedParameters
params.desc: An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.

params.textRaw: `...anonymousParameters` {null|number|bigint|string|Buffer|TypedArray|DataView} Zero or more values to bind to anonymous parameters.
params.name: ...anonymousParameters
params.desc: Zero or more values to bind to anonymous parameters.

methods.desc: This method executes a prepared statement and returns an iterator of objects. If the prepared statement does not return any results, this method returns an empty iterator. The prepared statement parameters are bound using the values in namedParameters and anonymousParameters.

methods.name: run

changes.description: Add support for `DataView` and typed array objects for `anonymousParameters`.

options.textRaw: `changes`: {number|bigint} The number of rows modified, inserted, or deleted by the most recently completed `INSERT`, `UPDATE`, or `DELETE` statement. This field is either a number or a `BigInt` depending on the prepared statement's configuration. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_changes64()`][].
options.name: changes
options.desc: The number of rows modified, inserted, or deleted by the most recently completed `INSERT`, `UPDATE`, or `DELETE` statement. This field is either a number or a `BigInt` depending on the prepared statement's configuration. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_changes64()`][].

options.textRaw: `lastInsertRowid`: {number|bigint} The most recently inserted rowid. This field is either a number or a `BigInt` depending on the prepared statement's configuration. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_last_insert_rowid()`][].
options.name: lastInsertRowid
options.desc: The most recently inserted rowid. This field is either a number or a `BigInt` depending on the prepared statement's configuration. This property is the result of [`sqlite3_last_insert_rowid()`][].

params.textRaw: `namedParameters` {Object} An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.
params.name: namedParameters
params.desc: An optional object used to bind named parameters. The keys of this object are used to configure the mapping.

params.textRaw: `...anonymousParameters` {null|number|bigint|string|Buffer|TypedArray|DataView} Zero or more values to bind to anonymous parameters.
params.name: ...anonymousParameters
params.desc: Zero or more values to bind to anonymous parameters.

methods.desc: This method executes a prepared statement and returns an object summarizing the resulting changes. The prepared statement parameters are bound using the values in namedParameters and anonymousParameters.

methods.name: setAllowBareNamedParameters

params.textRaw: `enabled` {boolean} Enables or disables support for binding named parameters without the prefix character.
params.name: enabled
params.desc: Enables or disables support for binding named parameters without the prefix character.

methods.desc:
The names of SQLite parameters begin with a prefix character. By default, node:sqlite requires that this prefix character is present when binding parameters. However, with the exception of dollar sign character, these prefix characters also require extra quoting when used in object keys.

To improve ergonomics, this method can be used to also allow bare named parameters, which do not require the prefix character in JavaScript code. There are several caveats to be aware of when enabling bare named parameters:

  • The prefix character is still required in SQL.
  • The prefix character is still allowed in JavaScript. In fact, prefixed names will have slightly better binding performance.
  • Using ambiguous named parameters, such as $k and @k, in the same prepared statement will result in an exception as it cannot be determined how to bind a bare name.

methods.name: setAllowUnknownNamedParameters

params.textRaw: `enabled` {boolean} Enables or disables support for unknown named parameters.
params.name: enabled
params.desc: Enables or disables support for unknown named parameters.

methods.desc: By default, if an unknown name is encountered while binding parameters, an exception is thrown. This method allows unknown named parameters to be ignored.

methods.name: setReadBigInts

params.textRaw: `enabled` {boolean} Enables or disables the use of `BigInt`s when reading `INTEGER` fields from the database.
params.name: enabled
params.desc: Enables or disables the use of `BigInt`s when reading `INTEGER` fields from the database.

methods.desc: When reading from the database, SQLite INTEGERs are mapped to JavaScript numbers by default. However, SQLite INTEGERs can store values larger than JavaScript numbers are capable of representing. In such cases, this method can be used to read INTEGER data using JavaScript BigInts. This method has no impact on database write operations where numbers and BigInts are both supported at all times.

properties.textRaw: `expandedSQL` {string} The source SQL expanded to include parameter values.
properties.name: expandedSQL
properties.desc: The source SQL text of the prepared statement with parameter placeholders replaced by the values that were used during the most recent execution of this prepared statement. This property is a wrapper around sqlite3_expanded_sql().
properties.shortDesc: The source SQL expanded to include parameter values.

properties.textRaw: `sourceSQL` {string} The source SQL used to create this prepared statement.
properties.name: sourceSQL
properties.desc: The source SQL text of the prepared statement. This property is a wrapper around sqlite3_sql().
properties.shortDesc: The source SQL used to create this prepared statement.

modules.textRaw: Type conversion between JavaScript and SQLite
modules.name: type_conversion_between_javascript_and_sqlite
modules.desc:
When Node.js writes to or reads from SQLite it is necessary to convert between JavaScript data types and SQLite's data types. Because JavaScript supports more data types than SQLite, only a subset of JavaScript types are supported. Attempting to write an unsupported data type to SQLite will result in an exception.

SQLite JavaScript
NULL <null>
INTEGER <number> or <bigint>
REAL <number>
TEXT <string>
BLOB <TypedArray> or <DataView>
modules.displayName: Type conversion between JavaScript and SQLite

methods.name: backup

changes.description: The `path` argument now supports Buffer and URL objects.

return.textRaw: Returns: {Promise} A promise that resolves when the backup is completed and rejects if an error occurs.
return.name: return
return.desc: A promise that resolves when the backup is completed and rejects if an error occurs.

params.textRaw: `sourceDb` {DatabaseSync} The database to backup. The source database must be open.
params.name: sourceDb
params.desc: The database to backup. The source database must be open.

params.textRaw: `path` {string | Buffer | URL} The path where the backup will be created. If the file already exists, the contents will be overwritten.
params.name: path
params.desc: The path where the backup will be created. If the file already exists, the contents will be overwritten.

params.textRaw: `options` {Object} Optional configuration for the backup. The following properties are supported:
params.name: options
params.desc: Optional configuration for the backup. The following properties are supported:

options.textRaw: `source` {string} Name of the source database. This can be `'main'` (the default primary database) or any other database that have been added with [`ATTACH DATABASE`][] **Default:** `'main'`.
options.name: source
options.desc: Name of the source database. This can be `'main'` (the default primary database) or any other database that have been added with [`ATTACH DATABASE`][]

options.textRaw: `target` {string} Name of the target database. This can be `'main'` (the default primary database) or any other database that have been added with [`ATTACH DATABASE`][] **Default:** `'main'`.
options.name: target
options.desc: Name of the target database. This can be `'main'` (the default primary database) or any other database that have been added with [`ATTACH DATABASE`][]

options.textRaw: `rate` {number} Number of pages to be transmitted in each batch of the backup. **Default:** `100`.
options.name: rate
options.desc: Number of pages to be transmitted in each batch of the backup.

options.textRaw: `progress` {Function} Callback function that will be called with the number of pages copied and the total number of pages.
options.name: progress
options.desc: Callback function that will be called with the number of pages copied and the total number of pages.

methods.desc:
This method makes a database backup. This method abstracts the sqlite3_backup_init(), sqlite3_backup_step() and sqlite3_backup_finish() functions.

The backed-up database can be used normally during the backup process. Mutations coming from the same connection - same <DatabaseSync> - object will be reflected in the backup right away. However, mutations from other connections will cause the backup process to restart.

const { backup, DatabaseSync } = require('node:sqlite');

(async () => {
  const sourceDb = new DatabaseSync('source.db');
  const totalPagesTransferred = await backup(sourceDb, 'backup.db', {
    rate: 1, // Copy one page at a time.
    progress: ({ totalPages, remainingPages }) => {
      console.log('Backup in progress', { totalPages, remainingPages });
    },
  });

  console.log('Backup completed', totalPagesTransferred);
})();

import { backup, DatabaseSync } from 'node:sqlite';

const sourceDb = new DatabaseSync('source.db');
const totalPagesTransferred = await backup(sourceDb, 'backup.db', {
  rate: 1, // Copy one page at a time.
  progress: ({ totalPages, remainingPages }) => {
    console.log('Backup in progress', { totalPages, remainingPages });
  },
});

console.log('Backup completed', totalPagesTransferred);

properties.name: constants
properties.desc: An object containing commonly used constants for SQLite operations.

modules.name: sqlite_constants
modules.desc: The following constants are exported by the sqlite.constants object.

modules.name: conflict_resolution_constants
modules.desc:
One of the following constants is available as an argument to the onConflict conflict resolution handler passed to database.applyChangeset(). See also Constants Passed To The Conflict Handler in the SQLite documentation.

Constant Description
SQLITE_CHANGESET_DATA The conflict handler is invoked with this constant when processing a DELETE or UPDATE change if a row with the required PRIMARY KEY fields is present in the database, but one or more other (non primary-key) fields modified by the update do not contain the expected "before" values.
SQLITE_CHANGESET_NOTFOUND The conflict handler is invoked with this constant when processing a DELETE or UPDATE change if a row with the required PRIMARY KEY fields is not present in the database.
SQLITE_CHANGESET_CONFLICT This constant is passed to the conflict handler while processing an INSERT change if the operation would result in duplicate primary key values.
SQLITE_CHANGESET_CONSTRAINT If foreign key handling is enabled, and applying a changeset leaves the database in a state containing foreign key violations, the conflict handler is invoked with this constant exactly once before the changeset is committed. If the conflict handler returns SQLITE_CHANGESET_OMIT, the changes, including those that caused the foreign key constraint violation, are committed. Or, if it returns SQLITE_CHANGESET_ABORT, the changeset is rolled back.
SQLITE_CHANGESET_FOREIGN_KEY If any other constraint violation occurs while applying a change (i.e. a UNIQUE, CHECK or NOT NULL constraint), the conflict handler is invoked with this constant.

One of the following constants must be returned from the onConflict conflict resolution handler passed to database.applyChangeset(). See also Constants Returned From The Conflict Handler in the SQLite documentation.

Constant Description
SQLITE_CHANGESET_OMIT Conflicting changes are omitted.
SQLITE_CHANGESET_REPLACE Conflicting changes replace existing values. Note that this value can only be returned when the type of conflict is either SQLITE_CHANGESET_DATA or SQLITE_CHANGESET_CONFLICT.
SQLITE_CHANGESET_ABORT Abort when a change encounters a conflict and roll back database.
